responses.content: Microsoft Cloud revenue surpassed $49B (26% growth) while commercial RPO exceeded $392B with a 2â€‘year duration; we closed a new definitive agreement with OpenAI extending IP rights through 2032 and incremental Azure commitments so the partnership continues driving mutual growth.

We are adding 80% more AI capacity this year, doubling the data center footprint in two years, launching Fairwater (2 GW) and the first GB300 cluster, and tuning the fleet to keep pretraining, post-training, inference, databases, streaming and sovereign workloads aligned.

Copilot now has 150M MAUs across information work, coding, security, science, health and consumer; we added Agent Mode, Teams mode, App Builder, and partners/agents from SAP, ServiceNow, Workday plus thousands of customer-built agents driving usage intensity and record seat adds.

Azure AI Foundry serves 80K customers with 11K models (including GPT-5, Grok-4); we launched the Microsoft Agent Framework and are delivering MAI models and Phi SLMs, with 60M downloads and 30% higher token throughput on GPT-4.1/5 over last year.
Q1 revenue was $77.7B (+18%/17% CC), operating income $38B (+24%/22% CC), GAAP EPS $3.72 ($4.13 non-GAAP) and capital returned $10.7B; Cloud gross margin 68% while operating margin hit 49%.

CapEx rose to $34.9B (half short-lived GPUs/CPUs, $11.1B finance leases); cash paid for PP&E was $19.4B. We generated $45.1B of ops cash (+32%) and $25.7B free cash flow (+33%), and returned $10.7B to shareholders.
Commercial bookings grew 112% (111% CC) on Azure/OpenAI commitments and $100M+ contracts; RPO reached $392B (+51%) with ~35% recognized next 12 months, showing demand is short-dated.

questions: With AGI talk and the large AI startups, is there anything that could change Microsoft's positioning, and how are you thinking about jagged intelligence?
Can you describe the breadth behind the 111% bookings growth and $392B RPO to give confidence it is durable and not overly concentrated?
Given the massive RPO and CapEx plans, how do you avoid overbuilding and ensure demand sustains?
Can you explain the $4.1B other income loss tied to OpenAI and what to expect going forward?
How do you evaluate the concentration risk of huge AI-native contracts and ensure guardrails when orders are much larger than the customers themselves?
Can you quantify the revenue impact from Azure being supply constrained and how you prevent workloads from migrating elsewhere?
How do you decide which demand to accept versus decline, particularly when other hyperscalers pursue similar large contracts?

metadata.source: Microsoft FY 2026 Q1 earnings call transcript
